qas.question: Why did George Francis Train refuse to extend the line?

context: Within the city there have been <a0_0>two<a0_0/> tram networks in operation. A proposal to develop a <b6_0>horse-drawn<b6_0/> tram (linking the city's railway termini) was made by American <a1_0><b5_0>George Francis Train<b5_0/><a1_0/> in the 1860s, and implemented in <a2_0>1872<a2_0/> by <b7_0><b9_0>the Cork Tramway Company<b9_0/><b7_0/>. However, the company ceased trading in <b10_0>1875<b10_0/> after <a3_0>Cork Corporation refused permission <b8_0>to extend the line<a3_0/>,<b8_0/> mainly <b12_0>because of objections from cab operators to the type of tracks<b12_0/> which – although they were laid to the Irish national railway gauge of <b11_0>5 ft 3in<b11_0/> – <a4_0><b13_0>protruded from the road surface<b13_0/><a4_0/>.[citation needed]
